title: Cat. 97  Women, Animals, and Foliage, 1898/99
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Women, Animals, and Foliage, from the Suite of Late Wood-Block Prints  
1898/99  
Second state of two  
Wood-block print in black ink on thin laid ivory Japanese paper, laid down on thin wove white Japanese paper; 163 × 305 mm (image); 228 × 305 mm (primary support); 237 × 318 mm (secondary support)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Edward McCormick Blair, 2002.257  
Guérin 59, Kornfeld 43 II/II, A

Women, Animals, and Foliage, from the Suite of Late Wood-Block Prints  
1898/99  
Second state of two  
Wood-block print in black ink on thin ivory Japanese paper, partially laid down on thin white Japanese paper; 163 × 305 mm (image); 228 × 305 mm (sheet); 242 × 335 mm (secondary support)  
Inscribed in the artist’s hand, lower left, in pen and black ink: No. / 29  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Purchase Fund 1949.933  
Guérin 59, Kornfeld 43 II/II, A

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Unlike the plates of the Noa Noa Suite, most of which Gauguin titled within each image, thirteen of the fifteen wood-block plates that make up the Suite of Late Wood-Block Prints are unnamed. Gauguin included a title in only two of the images, Te atua (The Gods) (cat. 103) and Soyez amoureuses, vous serez heureuses (Love, and You Will Be Happy) (cat. 100). The rest bear titles assigned after Gauguin died by authorities such as Marcel Guérin (who produced the first catalogue raisonné of the artist’s prints). He and others derived these titles by relating the images to works by Gauguin in other media depicting similar subject matter and carrying titles attributed to Gauguin such as At the Black Rocks (cat. 91).

This is one of four in the Suite of Late Wood-Block Prints that depict Tahitian subjects. The other three are Te arii vahine—opoi (Woman with Mangos—Tired) (cat. 96), Tahitian Carrying Bananas (cat. 98), and Plate with the Head of a Horned Devil (cat. 99) (see fig. 97.1). These thematically related works can stand on their own, but when placed end to end, they can also be read as a frieze-like arrangement. Gauguin left no instructions as to how to display the prints that make up the Suite of Late Wood-Block Prints. However, the inventory drawn up after his death, on May 8, 1903, of the contents of his “House of Pleasure” in Atuona, on the Marquesan island of Hiva Oa, lists “45 wood-block prints [gravures] pasted down the length of the partition walls.” Gauguin seems to have used three sets of this suite of prints to embellish his living quarters, employing a time-honored principle of interior decoration: the repetition of motifs, as exemplified by the frequent use of repeats in illustrated wallpaper borders.

This composition is rendered enigmatic by the isolation of its vignettes, one from the other. Resembling components of a collage, they are not united by a design element such as the ocher applied in the first stage of Soyez amoureuses, vous serez heureuses (Love, and You Will be Happy) (cat. 105) or Change of Residence (cat. 104). The wood matrix from which this image was made is in the Národní Galerie, Prague (fig. 97.2). Gauguin pasted the first state of the print, which is smaller in size and features fewer motifs than in the second (and final) state, onto the inside back cover of his 1902 manuscript L’esprit moderne et le catholicisme (Catholicism and the Modern Mind). It bears an inscription, in pen and ink, “—Paradis perdu—” (Paradise lost) (fig. 97.3).

The second-state impression (cats. 97.1 and 97.2) presents a composition that Gauguin expanded to the left. Beginning at the left and moving right, it includes a partly shrouded, standing woman, adjacent to whom are two rodents and a bird, suspended in midair. To their right and slightly above is another rodent. Below is a shrub or small tree that Gauguin transformed into a cartouche by including there his monogram and leaving space in which to inscribe, in pen and ink, a number: the Art Institute’s examples bear the numbers 29 (cat. 97.1) and 2 (cat. 97.2). A man and woman sit at the bottom center of the composition, while at the far right is a standing nude female.

Surrounding these motifs is a border comprising ground (at the bottom), tree trunks (at the sides), and branches (at the top). From the latter, leaves and blossoms extend into the space above the print’s other motifs. The tree trunks seem generic, formal devices that do not appear to relate botanically to the species of flora that the artist featured growing from the branches. Gauguin’s rendering of the leaves is specific enough to identify them as likely belonging to one of two coastal trees of the hibiscus family, the beach hibiscus and the portia tree. Gauguin’s rendering of these details is not precise enough to settle on one or the other. While the artist depicted the flowers mainly in their closed state, as they are in the early morning when they begin to unfurl, they resemble hibiscus blooms as well (see fig. 97.4 and fig. 97.5).

The visual program of this print is yet another example of Gauguin’s tireless extraction of images from the Buddhist friezes of the temple of Borobudur in Central Java, of which he had two photographs for his own artistic purposes (fig. 97.6 and fig. 97.7). Derived from a mongoose in one of the friezes is the animal enmeshed with a large leaf (see fig. 97.8). So too are all the other vignettes: the standing woman at the left (see fig. 97.9); the conflated forms of two rodents (which seem to be mating, although this does not seem to be the case with their hard-to-decipher prototype in Borobudur) and the bird (see fig. 97.10); the stylized small tree or shrub with Gauguin’s monogram (see fig. 97.11); the couple seated at the bottom center (see fig. 97.12); and the standing female nude, based on a representation of the Buddha (see fig. 97.13). The position of this woman’s hands derives from one of Buddha’s traditional gestures (mudras). It is also possible, given her placement in Gauguin’s print, that the nude may be reaching for one of the blossoms above her. She is further informed by the female featured in the 1892 oil painting Te nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (fig. 97.14 [W 455]), in a graphite nude study (fig. 97.15), and in the similarly titled plate 6 of the 1893–94 Noa Noa Suite (cat. 56) and other related works.

The prototype for the seated couple in the present print is found in Gauguin’s 1896 oil painting Eiaha ohipa (Do Not Work) (fig. 97.16 [W 538]). A few years after he had completed the Suite of Late Wood-Block Prints, the artist returned to his photograph of the similar pair at Borobudur when he executed his 1901 painting Et l’or de leur corps (And the Gold of Their Bodies) (fig. 97.17 [W 596]). A summary rendition of the couple appears in the background of Seated Female, a transfer monotype from 1902 (fig. 97.18 [Field 1973 43]), which Harriet K. Stratis discovered relates one-to-one in scale to the seated couple in the foreground of the present wood-block print, as well as to a watercolor monotype, Seated Male (fig. 97.19 [Field 1973 138]).  
Peter Zegers

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Marcel Guérin, L’oeuvre gravé de Gauguin (H. Floury, 1927; Alan Wofsy Fine Arts, 1980).

“45 gravures collées le long des cloisons,” in “Procès-verbal d’inventaire des meubles, meubles et objets de toute nature appartenent au sier Gauguin, Paul, Henri, Eugène, artiste peintre, décédé a Atuona, île Hiva-oa (Marquises), le 8 Mai 1903,” in Bulletin de la Société d’Études Océaniennes 10, no. 7 (Sept. 1977), p. 696.

Beach hibiscus (Hibiscus tilaceus); the portia tree (milo, miro) (Thespasia populnea, or, alternatively, the Hibiscus populneus).

</section><section id="figures">Top, Women, Animals, and Foliage, 1898/99 (cat. 97.1). Bottom, Women, Animals, and Foliage, 1898/99 (cat. 97.2).

fig. 97.1 Frieze composed of four plates from Gauguin’s Suite of Late Wood-Block Prints (1898/99). From left to right, Te arii vahine—opoi (Woman with Mangos—Tired); Women, Animals, and Foliage; Tahitian Carrying Bananas; and Plate with the Head of a Horned Devil. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1955.15, 2002.257, 1954.1192, and 1945.95.

fig. 97.2 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Women, Animals, and Foliage, 1899. Wood matrix; 16.1 × 33.4 × 2 cm (6.33 × 13.12 × 0.79 in.). Národní Galerie, Prague.

fig. 97.3 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). First-state impression of Women, Animals, and Foliage, 1899, pasted onto the inside back cover of Gauguin’s manuscript L’esprit moderne et le catholicisme (Catholicism and the Modern Mind), 1902. Wood-block print in black on paper; 16.3 × 30.5 cm (6 7/16 × 12 in.). Saint Louis Art Museum, gift of Vincent L. Price in memory of his parents, Marguerite and Vincent L. Price.

fig. 97.4 Leaves and flowers of the beach hibiscus tree (burau, parau, fau) (Hibiscus tilaceus).

fig. 97.5 Leaves and flowers of the portia tree (milo, miro) (Thespasia populnea).

fig. 97.6 Isidore van Kinsbergen (Dutch Flemish, 1821–1905). Photograph of relief (772–824) from the temple of Borobudur, central Java, Maitrakanyaka Arriving in a New Town, Welcomed by Sixteen Nymphs (lower register); Buddha Meeting Three Monks [?] on the Road to Benares (upper register), 1873. Albumen print from glass-plate negative; 30 × 40 cm (11 3/4 × 15 1/2 in.). Instituut Kern, Leiden.

fig. 97.7 Isidore van Kinsbergen (Dutch Flemish, 1821–1905). Photograph of relief (772–824) from the temple of Borobudur, Central Java, 1873, unidentified pavilion scene (lower register); Mara and His Demon Host Attack Siddhartha, Thus Hoping to Prevent His Enlightenment (upper register). Albumen print from glass-plate negative; 30 × 40 cm (11 3/4 × 15 1/2 in.). Instituut Kern, Leiden.

fig. 97.8 Left, Isidore van Kinsbergen (Dutch Flemish, 1821–1905). Photograph of relief (772–824) from the temple of Borobudur, Central Java, Maitrakanyaka Arriving in a New Town, Welcomed by Sixteen Nymphs (lower register), 1873 (detail showing a mongoose). Albumen print from glass-plate negative; 30 × 40 cm (11 3/4 × 15 1/2 in.). Instituut Kern, Leiden. Center, detail of Gauguin’s Women, Animals, and Foliage (1898/99) showing a rodent. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.257. Right, Javan mongoose (Herpestes javanicus).

fig. 97.9 Left, Isidore van Kinsbergen (Dutch Flemish, 1821–1905). Photograph of relief (772–824) from the temple of Borobudur, Central Java, Buddha Meeting Three Monks [?] on the Road to Benares (upper register), 1873 (detail showing the monk at far left). Albumen print from glass-plate negative; 30 × 40 cm (11 3/4 × 15 1/2 in.). Instituut Kern, Leiden. Right, detail of Gauguin’s Women, Animals, and Foliage (1898/99) showing the figure at the right. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.257.

fig. 97.10 Left, Isidore van Kinsbergen (Dutch Flemish, 1821–1905). Photograph of relief (772–824) from the temple of Borobudur, Central Java, Buddha Meeting Three Monks [?] on the Road to Benares (upper register), 1873 (detail showing rodents and a bird). Albumen print from glass-plate negative; 30 × 40 cm (11 3/4 × 15 1/2 in.). Instituut Kern, Leiden. Instituut Kern, Leiden. Right, detail of Gauguin’s Women, Animals, and Foliage (1898/99) showing rodents and a bird. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.257.

fig. 97.11 Left, Isidore van Kinsbergen (Dutch Flemish, 1821–1905). Photograph of relief (772–824) from the temple of Borobudur, Central Java, Maitrakanyaka Arriving in a New Town, Welcomed by Sixteen Nymphs (lower register), 1873 (detail showing a small tree or shrub). Albumen print from glass-plate negative; 30 × 40 cm (11 3/4 × 15 1/2 in.). Instituut Kern, Leiden. Right, detail of Gauguin’s Women, Animals, and Foliage (1898/99) showing a small tree or shrub with the artist’s monogram. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.257.

fig. 97.12 Left, Isidore van Kinsbergen (Dutch Flemish, 1821–1905). Photograph of relief (772–824) from the temple of Borobudur, Central Java, unidentified pavilion scene (lower register), 1873 (detail showing the enthroned king of Benares and his wife, Malika). Albumen print from glass-plate negative; 30 × 40 cm (11 3/4 × 15 1/2 in.). Instituut Kern, Leiden. Right, detail of Gauguin’s Women, Animals, and Foliage (1898/99) showing a seated couple. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.257.

fig. 97.13 Left, Isidore van Kinsbergen (Dutch Flemish, 1821–1905). Photograph of relief (772–824) from the temple of Borobudur, Central Java, Buddha Meeting Three Monks [?] on the Road to Benares (upper register), 1873 (detail showing the standing Buddha). Albumen print from glass-plate negative; 30 × 40 cm (11 3/4 × 15 1/2 in.). Instituut Kern, Leiden. Right, detail of Gauguin’s Women, Animals, and Foliage (1898/99) showing the figure at right. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.257.

fig. 97.14 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Te nave nave fenua (The Delightful Land), 1892. Oil on canvas; 91 ×72 cm (35 13/16 ×28 3/8 in.). Ohara Museum of Art, Kurashiki.

fig. 97.15 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Study for “Te nave nave fenua” (The Delightful Land), 1891/93. Graphite on paper; 15 × 11.1 cm (5 15/16 × 4 3/8 in.). Private collection.

fig. 97.16 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Eiaha ohipa (Do Not Work), 1896. Oil on canvas; 65 × 75 cm (25 9/16 × 29 1/2 in.). Pushkin State Museum of Fine Arts, Moscow.

fig. 97.17 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Et l’or de leur corps (And the Gold of Their Bodies), 1901. Oil on canvas; 67 × 76.5 cm (26 3/8 × 30 1/8 in.). Musée d’Orsay, Paris, RF 1944.2.

fig. 97.18 Left, detail of Gauguin’s Sister of Charity (1902) showing the two figures. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.239. Right, tracing of the figures in Gauguin’s Women, Animals, and Foliage (1898/99) showing the one-to-one relationship of the figures with those in Sister of Charity. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.257.

fig. 97.19 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Seated Male, 1902. Watercolor monotype on paper; 14.6 × 16.2 cm (5 3/4 × 6 3/8 in.). Szépmüvészeti Múzuem, Budapest.
